title: 115_s716
content: The Act may be cited as the "Dollar-for-Dollar Deficit Reduction Act" and includes an amendment to Title 31. The "Dollar-for-Dollar Deficit Reduction Act" amends Title 31 to include a new section on debt limit control, allowing the Secretary of the Treasury to issue a warning to Congress in case of a near breach of the public debt limit. This warning would outline when extraordinary measures may be needed to fund the government. The Secretary of the Treasury can take action in the event of a debt limit breach to keep the government functioning. A "near breach" is when the debt limit will be reached within 60 days despite extraordinary measures. The President must submit a request for a debt limit increase along with proposed legislation. The proposed legislation accompanying a debt limit increase must include spending reductions over the current and following 10 years, excluding net interest savings. The savings calculation should align with the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985. SEC. 3. CONGRESSIONAL REQUIREMENT TO RESTRAIN SPENDING WHILE RAISING THE DEBT LIMIT. Title III of the Congress and Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include a debt limit increase point of order. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include a point of order that prohibits considering any bill increasing the statutory debt limit unless it includes net spending reductions over the current and next 10 fiscal years. Net interest savings cannot be counted towards the required spending reductions. The savings must be calculated by the Congressional Budget Office against a budget baseline consistent with the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act. The Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 excludes emergency spending from the budget baseline. The Senate and House cannot vote on increasing the public debt limit without a cost estimate from the Congressional Budget Office available for 24 hours. Provisions shifting outlays or revenues outside the 10-year window are prohibited. The Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 requires a three-fifths Senate vote to waive or appeal subsection (a)(1).
